thread.title: Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari
thread.title_full: Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari

title: Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari
text:
Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari Just wow. Post to Facebook Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari Just wow.  //ftw.usatoday.com/2017/03/kentucky-wildcats-malik-monk-shot-john-calipari-play-buzzer-video-north-carolina-elite-eight-ncaa-tournament   Kentucky nearly forced OT with play that haunted Calipari Andrew Joseph 8:01 p.m. ET March 26, 2017 3 Shares 
The final minute of North Carolina's 75-73 Elite Eight win against Kentucky was nothing short of absolutely bonkers. 
Just when Kentucky seemed done, North Carolina's mistakes and the Wildcats' clutch shooting brought Kentucky right back. With under 14 seconds to go, Kentucky had the ball down 3. The play that head coach John Calipari chose to run, though, had an eery similarity to the arguably the toughest moment of Calipari's career. And it worked. NEVER CHANGE, MARCH. pic.twitter.com/1H4aiOLXYG — CBS Sports (@CBSSports) March 26, 2017 
That play is what Kansas head coach Bill Self calls "Chop," and it broke into the mainstream during the 2008 national title game. Look familiar? 
On Sunday, Isaiah Briscoe played the role of Sherron Collins, and Malik Monk was Mario Chalmers. They ran literally the same play to the same side and got the same result - an incredible game-tying 3. 
Had North Carolina's Luke Maye not hit that winning jumper with .3 seconds remaining, we would all be discussing how Calipari brilliantly turned a play that has haunted him for years into a ticket to the Final Four. 
It nearly worked out that way … until it didn't. Read or Share this story: http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/03/kentucky-wildcats-malik-monk-shot-john-calipari-play-buzzer-video-north-carolina-elite-eight-ncaa-tournament Most Popular NFL mock draft 4.0: How has free agency altered outlook? 5.5k Shares
